def detect_outliers(df,features):
    outlier_indices = []
    for c in features:
        # 1st quartile
        Q1 = np.percentile(df[c],25)
        # 3rd quartile
        Q3 =np.percentile(df[c],75)
        # IQR
        IQR = Q3 - Q1
        #Outlier Step
        outlier_step = IQR * 1.5
        # Detect outlier and their indices
        outlier_list_col = df[(df[c] <Q1 - outlier_step) | (df[c] > Q3 + outlier_step)].index
        #store indices
        outlier_indices.extend(outlier_list_col)
        
    outlier_indices = Counter(outlier_indices)
    multiple_outliers = list(i for i,v in outlier_indices.items() if v > 2) 
    
    return multiple_outliers

In order to train our model properly and accurate, we need to identify discrete values that distort the data statistically. Example:
Imagine you are working in a company and there are 21 people working in different fields other than you. Everyone gets different wages according to their field of expertise. Your boss decided to raise everyone. There are also those who receive minimum wages in this company and there are also those who work for a lot of money. If your boss will raise according to the average wages of the employees, the average value may be higher due to the outlier values. In such a situation, your boss may stop raising. That's why we subtract outlier values ​​by using outlier detection and operate according to our raw values.
